**The Lost Generation of Democracy: Spain's Rise of the Far-Right**
Spain is joining the list of countries where young people are fueling the rise of the far-right and authoritarian ultraderecha. A decade ago, one in three young people expressed their intention to vote for the left, while only one in four thought they would vote for the right. However, in recent surveys, the correlation has been reversed: four in ten young people between 18 and 24 years old support the right (and two-thirds of them support the ultraderecha), while only two in ten choose left-wing options. This age group now accounts for over three million voters out of a total of 37 million. The most significant aspect of this ideological shift is the rapid and unprecedented growth of the ultraderecha among young people. In the CIS survey of May, the conservative space was divided equally between the Partido Popular (20%) and the ultraderecha of Vox and Alvise (22%) among those under 24. A similar correlation occurred in the 25-34 age group (a contingent that accounts for another five million voters). However, this pattern is maintained, intensified, in the CIS survey of July: the ultraderecha has a 13-point lead over the PP in the 18-24 age group, and more than six points in the next age group (25-34 years). The mutation of the ideological youth in Spain has no precedents. With the country just out of the dictatorship, young people leaned clearly to the left (and their location on the ideological scale reflected this, as they now sit one point to the right). Even in the early 90s, the percentage of young people under 35 who supported the PSOE or more left-wing forces doubled or even tripled the rate of adhesions to the right. The data from last May provides clues about the causes of this change. If the declared voting intention is segregated by sex, the result is very eloquent: among men aged 18-24, Vox outperforms the PP by almost eleven points (and seven in the 25-34 age group). However, among young women, it is the Partido Popular that outperforms the ultras: by 12 points in the 18-24 age group, and seven in the 25-34 age group. In short, the ultraderechization of young men has something of an egoistic rebellion against the advance of gender parity. Nevertheless, Spain is not an exceptional case. Other Western countries are experiencing a sustained rise in extreme right-wing parties with the decisive support of new generations. The recent Polish presidential elections are a good example: the ultra-candidate clearly won among those under 40 (and with a greater advantage among men). And something similar occurred in the German legislative elections, although here the young people radicalized towards the two extremes (AfD, to the right, and Die Linke, to the left). Of course, there are exceptions. In the Canadian legislative elections, the Liberal Party (center-left) won over the Conservative Party (close to Trump) thanks to the vote of those under 35 (and especially women). In contrast, the age group between 35 and 54 leaned towards the conservatives. However, unlike what happens not only on the other side of the Atlantic, in the Spanish case, the low level of education still does not play decisively in favor of the ultraderecha, which is residual among those who barely went to school (46% of them vote for the PSOE). And although Vox is also marginal among the working class, it is starting to have presence among the poorest.

- A structural rightward shift among Spanish youth, especially young men, has been well documented; traditional left/right polarization has eroded, and youth identification with the right/far-right is at unprecedented levels.
- Vox’s digital/meme-driven strategy, issue salience (primarily immigration, cost of living, anti-establishment sentiments), and pan-European youth trends support continued or further gains.

- All analyses referenced similar base rates and comparative cases (especially Germany and France), noting that Spanish youth support for the far-right, while remarkable, tracks with broader European developments.

In sum, the experts agree it is more likely than not that Vox will surpass 27% in the final 40dB youth poll, but there is notable residual uncertainty due to abstention, gender splits, potential right-populist fragmentation, and polling volatility.
